name: Native to the USA or Not? Quiz | Environment | 25 Questions

questions.text: Ringneck pheasant, a game bird common in the Midwestern cornfields.
questions.explanation:
Not & Not native.

	They were brought from China. Game departments spend hundreds of thousands of dollars every year raising and releasing them to be shot by hunters.

questions.text: Rhododendron, a bush familiar for its beautiful flowers.
questions.explanation:
Native.

	Many species of rhododendrons are found on both coasts.

questions.text: The wild turkey, a familiar bird.
questions.explanation:
Native.

	Benjamin Franklin wanted to make the turkey the national bird!

questions.text: The most common tumbleweed, tumbling across the screen in countless Western movies.
questions.explanation:
Not & Not native.

	Really called the 'Russian thistle', the tumbleweed was probably introduced in grain shipments from Asia.

questions.text: The nutria (or coypu) a furbearing rodent found in swamps in the South.
questions.explanation:
Not & Not native.

	Originally native to South America, they were often deliberately released by fur farmers.

questions.text: Rainbow trout, a popular game fish.
questions.explanation:
Native.

	Rainbow trout are native to the west coast of the US. They have been introduced to other places. However, many wild trout are being decimated by an introduced pathogen called 'whirling disease'.

questions.text: The mallard duck, our commonest wild duck.
questions.explanation:
Native.

	Mallards crossbreed readily with domestic ducks as well.

questions.text: Water hyacinth, a lake plant with pretty purple flowers.
questions.explanation:
Not & Not native.

	Introduced from Central America, this fast-growing plant has clogged many waterways.

questions.text: The wild pig, found primarily in wooded areas in the West and South.
questions.explanation:
Not & Not native.

	They are descendants of escaped domestic pigs. They cause tremendous ecological damage, especially in fragile ecosystems like Hawaii.

questions.text: The crabapple tree, producer of small, tart fruit.
questions.explanation:
Native.

	Crabapple, apples and the like are actually members of the rose family.

questions.text: The blueberry, commonly found in pancakes!
questions.explanation:
Native.

	They grow in boggy, acid-soiled places in the East and North.

questions.text: Sagebrush, the fragrant symbol of the West.
questions.explanation:
Native.

	Sagebrush is not related to sage, which is also native.

questions.text: The beaver, chief dam-builder.
questions.explanation:
Native.

	Beavers are also found in Europe. There is debate over whether they are a different species.

questions.text: Wild mustard, a common plant with yellow flowers.
questions.explanation:
Not & Not native.

	The hills of California are covered with blooming mustard in the spring. It is said that the missionaries scattered the seeds to mark their trails.

questions.text: Tamarisk, an evergreen tree found along desert washes.
questions.explanation:
Not & Not native.

	The tamarisk, introduced from Asia, robs native plants of scarce water.

questions.text: The whitetail deer, most common hoofed animal in the U.S.
questions.explanation:
Native.

	Whitetails like disturbed, cut-over areas, and are more numerous now than they were 100 years ago.

questions.text: The brown trout, a common game fish.
questions.explanation:
Not & Not native.

	The brown trout outcompetes native fish for food.

questions.text: The redwood, tallest tree in the U.S.
questions.explanation:
Native.

	There is a species called "dawn redwood" from China as well.

questions.text: The starling, a common and noisy bird.
questions.explanation:
Not & Not native.

	Starlings were introduced by a man attempting to introduce all birds mentioned in Shakespeare to the U.S.

questions.text: The eucalyptus, common tree in California.
questions.explanation:
Not & Not native.

	They were introduced from Australia. They produce a toxin in their roots that kills plants around them, and they hog scarce water. Their foliage is poisonous and few animals can eat them.

questions.text: The house mouse, common unwanted guest.
questions.explanation:
Not & Not native.

	They have followed humans all over the world.

questions.text: The coyote, 'song dog' whose howls can be heard in almost every state.
questions.explanation:
Native.

	The adaptable coyote has filled the niche of the persecuted wolf and increased its range dramatically.

questions.text: The chukar partridge, a game bird found in rocky desert areas.
questions.explanation:
Not & Not native.

	Like the ringneck, this Asian bird was introduced explicitly for hunting.

questions.text: The red fox, a wily and adaptable canine.
questions.explanation:
Native.

	The red fox originally was found in only a limited area. Foxhunters and fur farmers spread the species.

questions.text: Cougar, which is also known as the puma or mountain lion.
questions.explanation:
Native.

	Found in western parts of the USA and in Florida, as well as in Canada and South America.
